transcripts.text: Lucky me.  I had another run-in with Derby Police, this time inspired by a PCSO that overstepped his authority.  The events in this video actually occurred in November of last year.  The reason I didn't upload it at the time is because I wanted to do as much as I could to further the inevitable civil claim that arose from this.
That often takes so long that by the time they've concluded, everybody's forgotten the original incident.

And I didn't want that to happen here.  I also wanted to get a full investigation report from the Professional Standards Department, which is nearly always the first step in bringing a claim.  And that in itself took six months to complete.  so i was in the city centre of derby late last year on my way to collect my daughter when i noticed a group of pcsos stood on the street gossiping.  as i walked past i made a comment to another member of the public at how many of them were just stood around doing nothing.  This prompted one of the female PCSOs to protest rudely and aggressively.  I just turned to her and said, I was talking about you, not to you, and kept walking.
But she persisted, and quite frankly, it got my back up, having some crash test dummy of a cop trying to admonish me in public.  So I responded with, shut up, you stupid woman.

nothing unreasonable in that.  shutting up was a fair request and by virtue of the fact that she was a p?  c s o she was clearly stupid.  this prompted p c s o hudor to peel himself away from the group and follow after me.
he told me to stop.  I told him I was under no obligation to stop as I'd done nothing wrong and PCSOs have no powers to detain.
Certainly not in Derby anyway.  Lo and behold, he actually had the brass balls to put his hand on me and physically stop me in the street.  And that's where my camera comes out.
I can see your designation card.  Show it to me, please.  Right here.  Well, let's have a look at it.  I did not throw it at your colleague.

Any PCSO that refuses to show their designation card is no longer acting in the execution of his duty, and the same would go for any officer that then acted upon his instruction.  Besides which, nothing in the Anti-Social Behaviour Crime and Policing Act provides a PCSO with the power to collect a person's details.  let alone physically detain someone to do so.  hodor says i was causing harassment alarm and distress which is a catch cry for petty policing these days but all he's done is provide the definition of antisocial behavior.  he hasn't stated which section of the act he's attempting to enforce which he is obliged to do.

as it turns out it was trying to apply section thirty five which is a power to issue a dispersal notice and something that the police keep getting wrong.  that's because they believe section thirty five provides them with the power to demand details under threat of arrest.  it doesn't and no offense is created by refusing to give your details or refusing to accept a dispersal notice.

Section 38 provides a list of entries that must be made on the notice, including a record of the individual to whom the direction is given.  But Section 38 is a requirement of the issuing authority, not of the public, and in any event, name and address is not mentioned as part of the record keeping.
Instead, the term a record of the individual is used, which means that a description of the person would suffice.
Section 39 of the Act gives a comprehensive list of offences that could arise from dispersal and failure to provide details is not one of them.
Only a failure to comply with a dispersal notice or a failure to surrender requested items is an offence, not failure to assist an officer in completing his records.

but this is all academic because section thirty five also states that an official authorisation by a senior officer must be enforced before any police officer or designated official can issue a dispersal notice.  guess what there wasn't one i know because i checked.
It had expired at 3pm that day, before these events occurred.

another reason i waited to upload this video is to ensure that it was well outside the six month time limit of summary offences so that the police could not then maliciously prosecute me for an imaginary public order offence something derbyshire police would most certainly do.  officer snowflake tried that last year trying to prosecute me for saying no shit to him and fouled but this time i would not even give the police the satisfaction of summonsing me to court unluckily for this lot.  they picked on the very person who knows exactly how to sue them and ensure they're suitably reprimanded.
